Contradict fact: The claim that the free Covid-19 vaccines in South Korea will be from Celltrion contradicts the statements from officials at the Ministry of Health and Welfare, the Korea Disease Control and Prevention Agency (KDCA), and Celltrion itself, who all deny that Celltrion is developing or producing Covid-19 vaccines.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks sufficient support as there is no evidence provided to back up the assertion that the free vaccines will be from Celltrion. The only source cited is a Facebook post and a screenshot of President Moon Jae-in's address, neither of which provide any concrete information about the source of the vaccines.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the free vaccines in South Korea will come from Celltrion based on a Facebook post and a screenshot of President Moon Jae-in's address. However, there is no direct evidence or official confirmation to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: An alternative explanation is that the claim is based on misinformation or misunderstanding. The KDCA spokesperson and Celltrion both state that Celltrion is not developing or producing Covid-19 vaccines, suggesting that the claim may be inaccurate or misinformed.
